name: nytimes
text:
Gun deaths are rare in Britain and firearms are strictly controlled — but American guns are being quietly smuggled into the country.

Police fear these illegal weapons are fueling gang-related crime, writes @jane__bradley. https://t.co/WFIAEuJ5xl

name: nytimes
text:
Josh Bains was 28 when he was killed after an argument over a drug debt of about $50, just a few miles from the sleepy English village where he grew up. 

He was killed with a gun that had come from the U.S. https://t.co/WFIAEuJ5xl https://t.co/hjTAkqFnid

name: nytimes
text:
His was one of a rising number of gun deaths in recent years that have the British authorities worried about a growing gun smuggling pipeline from the U.S. 

The gun used to kill Josh Bains is banned outright in Britain. https://t.co/WFIAEuJ5xl

name: nytimes
text:
Most illegal firearms in Britain still come from Europe. 

But at least 782 American guns have been discovered by the British police since 2017. Experts say the number that the police do not discover is likely far higher. https://t.co/WFIAEuJ5xl https://t.co/n1rbiD7UE4

name: nytimes
text:
Gun deaths are extremely rare in Britain, and very few people, even police officers, carry firearms. 

But the new influx of weapons from the U.S. comes as serious violent crime has risen sharply. https://t.co/WFIAEuJ5xl https://t.co/VbDmiZcwmX

name: nytimes
text:
The British police have traced some of these guns back to loosely regulated gun fairs in states like Florida. 

Investigators have also seized American weapons being smuggled on a container ship and hidden in car engines. https://t.co/WFIAEuJ5xl https://t.co/U2cYc6Wuhc

name: nytimes
text:
In many cases, the trade in smuggled guns is driven by gangs who traffic drugs from British cities to smaller towns and rural areas — known as “county lines” gangs — like Josh Bains’s killers. 

They were sentenced to life in prison last summer. https://t.co/WFIAEuJ5xl https://t.co/9awShJlxrD

name: nytimes
text: British authorities fear that post-Brexit, when borders with the E.U. will be more tightly regulated, the illegal gun trade from the U.S. could accelerate – especially given the Trump administration’s broad support for the American gun industry. https://t.co/WFIAEuJ5xl https://t.co/eDtZL9J0oT

name: nytimes
text: “If suddenly guns became the weapon of choice as opposed to a knife, we’d be in a really difficult situation,” said Matthew Perfect, who leads the firearms unit of the UK's National Crime Agency. https://t.co/WFIAEuJ5xl
